summary: Due to an injury, I know my upper body will atrophy over the next few months. Should I be eating much more calories to prevent...
title: Due to an injury, I know my upper body will atrophy over the next few months. Should I be eating much more calories to prevent this? via /r/Fitness
body:
Due to arm injury, I may be out of action in terms of any upper body work for at least a couple months, maybe even longer.

Because of this I know my upper body will undoubtedly begin to atrophy.

I’ll still be working legs and doing cardio, but to prevent atrophy as much as possible in my upper body, should I be eating more calories?

EDIT: My concern is that I don’t want my upper body to turn “doughy” from a combination of surplus calories and lack of exercise, but I think less calories would cause more atrophy?



Submitted November 04, 2018 at 03:40AM by inaarbn
via reddit https://ift.tt/2qr4un5

summary: Prescribing unnecessary antibiotics is the path of least resistance
title: Prescribing unnecessary antibiotics is the path of least resistance
body:
During my urgent care shifts, I see 20 to 30 people with viral upper respiratory infections. They are all feeling miserable, and they just want to feel better. They want an impressive-sounding diagnosis to justify their suffering to themselves, their spouses, and their bosses. They want a prescription medication which will immediately cure their illness,

Find jobs at Careers by KevinMD.com. Search thousands of physician, PA, NP, and CRNA jobs now. Learn more.

summary: What causes lower back pain in the elderly?
title: What causes lower back pain in the elderly?
excerpt:
Why does back pain happen to older people in particular?
One of the most common pains in older people is back pain, because it is very painful and prevents them from performing many of the daily tasks or even walking and moving from one place to another.
Many people suffer from the problem of back pain because of the many reasons that stimulate the appearance of symptoms on the body, but the elderly are the most vulnerable to this problem in particular, because of the weakness of their muscles and inability to bear the tasks of life as it was in the youth, Or severe injury to many of the gaps in the spine, which is called osteoporosis, or rupture of tendons and muscles of the back and the occurrence of muscle spasms that usually come Some common reasons are:
Back pain due to osteoporosis,
Inflammation of the back joints,
Refraction of a vertebral column,
The ruptured tendon in the back,
Obesity
